sections.title: Early life
sections.paragraphs: Alfonso Cuarón Orozco was born in [[Mexico City]] on 28 November 1961, the son of Alfredo Cuarón, a doctor specializing in nuclear medicine, and Cristina Orozco, a pharmaceutical biochemist.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Valdes |first1=Marcela |title=After ‘Gravity,’ Alfonso Cuarón Had His Pick of Directing Blockbusters. Instead, He Went Home to Make ‘Roma.’ |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/13/magazine/alfonso-cuaron-roma-mexico-netflix.html |accessdate=26 February 2019 |work=The New York Times |date=13 December 2018}}</ref> He has two brothers, [[Carlos Cuarón|Carlos]], also a filmmaker,<ref>{{cite news|first1=Interviews: Beverley|last1=D’Silva|accessdate=2019-12-23|title=Relative Values: Alfonso Cuaron and his brother Carlos|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/relative-values-alfonso-cuaron-and-his-brother-carlos-pmd9586dqjp|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=18 October 2009|issn=0956-1382|via=www.thetimes.co.uk}}</ref> and Alfredo, a conservation biologist.{{cn|date=December 2019}} Cuarón studied philosophy at the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] (UNAM) and filmmaking at CUEC ([[Centro Universitario de Estudios Cinematográficos]]),<ref name="filmquarterly">{{cite web|accessdate=2019-12-23|title=Roma: Repatriation vs. Exploitation|url=https://filmquarterly.org/2019/06/07/roma-repatriation-vs-exploitation/|date=7 June 2019}}</ref> a school within the same university. There, he met the director Carlos Marcovich and [[cinematographer]] [[Emmanuel Lubezki]],<ref name="filmquarterly"/> and they made what would be his first short film, ''Vengeance Is Mine.''{{cn|date=December 2019}}

values.name: title
values.value: After ‘Gravity,’ Alfonso Cuarón Had His Pick of Directing Blockbusters. Instead, He Went Home to Make ‘Roma.’

values.name: title
values.value: Relative Values: Alfonso Cuaron and his brother Carlos

sections.title: Career
sections.paragraphs:
{{More citations needed section|date=February 2019}}

===Early career===
[[File:Alfonso_Cuarón_(1998).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Alfonso at the [[Festival Internacional de Cine en Guadalajara]] in 1998.]]
Cuarón began working on television in Mexico, first as a technician and then as a director. His television work led to assignments as an assistant director for several film productions including ''[[La Gran Fiesta]]'', ''[[Gaby: A True Story]]'' and ''[[Romero (film)|Romero]]'', and in 1991, he landed his first big-screen directorial assignment.

===''Sólo con Tu Pareja''===
''[[Sólo con Tu Pareja]]'' is a sex comedy about a womanizing businessman (played by [[Daniel Giménez Cacho]]) who, after having sex with an attractive nurse, is fooled into believing he's contracted [[AIDS]]. In addition to writing, producing and directing, Cuarón co-edited the film with Luis Patlán.<ref>{{cite news|first1=A. O.|last1=Scott|accessdate=2019-12-23|title=Sólo Con Tu Pareja - Review - Movies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/20/movies/20solo.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=20 September 2006|issn=0362-4331|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>

The film, which also starred cabaret singer [[Astrid Hadad]] and model/actress [[Claudia Ramírez]] (with whom Cuarón was linked between 1989 and 1993), was a big hit in Mexico. After this success, director [[Sydney Pollack]] hired Cuarón to direct an episode of ''[[Fallen Angels (American TV series)|Fallen Angels]]'', a series of [[neo-noir]] stories produced for the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] premium cable network in 1993; other directors who worked on the series included [[Steven Soderbergh]], [[Jonathan Kaplan]], [[Peter Bogdanovich]] and [[Tom Hanks]].

===American debut, ''Y Tu Mamá También'' and international success===
[[File:Alfonso_Cuarón_y_Clive_Owen_(Children_of_men).jpg|left|thumb|250px|Alfonso Cuarón and [[Clive Owen]], who worked together on '' Children of Men''.]]
In 1995, Cuarón released his first feature film produced in the United States, ''[[A Little Princess (1995 film)|A Little Princess]]'', an adaptation of [[Frances Hodgson Burnett]]'s classic novel. Cuarón's next feature was also a literary adaptation, a modernized version of [[Charles Dickens]]'s ''[[Great Expectations (1998 film)|Great Expectations]]'' starring [[Ethan Hawke]], [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] and [[Robert De Niro]].

Cuarón's next project found him returning to Mexico with a Spanish-speaking cast to film ''[[Y Tu Mamá También]]'', starring [[Gael García Bernal]], [[Diego Luna]] and [[Maribel Verdú]]. It was a provocative and controversial road comedy about two sexually obsessed teenagers who take an extended road trip with an attractive married woman who is much older than them. The film's open portrayal of sexuality and frequent rude humor, as well as the politically and socially relevant asides, made the film an international hit and a major success with critics. Cuarón shared an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] with co-writer and brother [[Carlos Cuarón]].

In 2004, Cuarón directed the third film in the successful ''[[Harry Potter (film series)|Harry Potter]]'' series, ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]''. Cuarón faced criticism from some ''[[Harry Potter]]'' fans for his approach to the film. At the time of the movie's release, however, author [[J. K. Rowling]], who had seen and loved Cuarón's film ''Y Tu Mamá También'', said that it was her personal favorite from the series so far.<ref>[http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/news_view.cfm?id=76 J.K. Rowling] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204052946/http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/news_view.cfm?id=76 |date=4 February 2007}} Accessed 17 January 2007.</ref> Critically, the film was also better received than the first two installments, with some critics remarking its new tone and for being the first ''Harry Potter'' film to truly capture the essence of the novels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/harry_potter_and_the_prisoner_of_azkaban/|title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban|publisher=}}</ref>

Cuarón's feature ''[[Children of Men]]'', an adaptation of the [[P. D. James]] [[The Children of Men|novel]] starring [[Clive Owen]], [[Julianne Moore]] and [[Michael Caine]], received wide critical acclaim, including three [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations. Cuarón himself received two nominations for his work on the film in [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing|Best Film Editing]] (with [[Alex Rodríguez (film editor)|Alex Rodríguez]]) and [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Best Adapted Screenplay]] (with several collaborators).

He created the production and distribution company [[Esperanto Filmoj]] (''Esperanto Films'', named because of his support for the international language [[Esperanto]]<ref>[http://esperantodocumentary.com/blog/an-interview-with-director-alfonso-cuaron Interview] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702024121/http://esperantodocumentary.com/blog/an-interview-with-director-alfonso-cuaron |date=2 July 2014 }} by [[Sam Green]] with Cuarón.</ref>), which has credits in the films ''[[Duck Season]]'', ''[[Pan's Labyrinth]]'', and ''[[Gravity (2013 film)|Gravity]]''.

Cuarón also directed the controversial public service announcement "I Am Autism" for [[Autism Speaks]] that was criticized by disability rights groups for its negative portrayal of autism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asansouthwestohio.blogspot.com/2009/09/autistic-community-condemns-autism.html|title=Autistic Self Advocacy Network, SW Ohio: Autistic Community Condemns Autism Speaks|last=Asansouthwestohio|date=23 September 2009|publisher=}}</ref>

===Awards recognition===
[[File:Alfonso_Cuarón,_President_jury_Venezia_72_(25805089406).jpg|thumb|250px|left|Cuaron at the [[72nd Venice International Film Festival]]]]

[[File:Alfonso Cuarón en Morelia.jpg|thumb|Alfonso Cuarón in Morelia International Film Festival]]
In 2010, Cuarón began to develop the film ''[[Gravity (2013 film)|Gravity]]'', a drama set in space. He was joined by producer [[David Heyman]], with whom Cuarón worked on ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]''. Starring [[Sandra Bullock]] and [[George Clooney]], the film was released in the fall of 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/05/14/sandra-bullock-gravity-2013|title=Movie News: Movie Reviews, Trailers, Photos - EW.com|publisher=}}</ref> and opened the [[70th Venice International Film Festival]] in August. On 12 January 2014, Alfonso accepted the [[Golden Globe Award]] in the category of [[Golden Globe Award for Best Director|Best Director]]. The film received ten [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations, including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] and [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]]. Cuarón won for Best Directing, becoming the first Latin American to win the award,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/film-tv/a26346517/who-is-alfonso-cuaron-roma-director/|title=Who Is Roma Director Alfonso Cuarón? You've Definitely Seen His Incredible Movies|work=[[Harper's Bazaar]]|date=February 23, 2019|accessdate=February 25, 2019}}</ref> while he and [[Mark Sanger]] received the award for [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing|Best Film Editing]].<ref name="Oscars search">{{cite web|url=http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/|title=Academy Awards Search|publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]|accessdate=February 25, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723203650/http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/|archive-date=23 July 2008|url-status=dead}}</ref>

In 2013, Cuarón created ''[[Believe (TV series)|Believe]]'', a science fiction/fantasy/adventure series that was broadcast as part of the 2013–14 United States network television schedule on NBC as a mid-season entry. The series was created by Cuarón for Bad Robot Productions and Warner Bros. Television. In 2014, ''[[TIME]]'' placed him in its list of "[[100 Most Influential People in the World]]" – Pioneers.<ref>{{cite magazine | title =The 100 Most Influential People – Pioneers: Alfonso Cuarón |magazine= [[TIME.com]]| url = http://time.com/70897/alfonso-cuaron-2014-time-100/|date=23 April 2014| accessdate = 2014-04-26}}</ref>

In May 2015, Cuarón was announced as the President of the Jury for the [[72nd Venice International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.labiennale.org/en/cinema/news/11-05.html |title=Director Alfonso Cuarón President of the International Jury for the Venezia 72 Competition |date=11 May 2015 |accessdate=11 May 2015 |work=Venice Biennale}}</ref>

Production began in fall 2016 for Cuarón's eighth film, ''[[Roma (2018 film)|Roma]],'' a tale of a housekeeper for a middle class Mexican family in 1970s Mexico City, based on the life of his family's longtime maid, Liboria Rodríguez.<ref>{{cite news|first1=Guy|last1=Lodge|accessdate=2019-12-23|title=Roma: why Alfonso Cuaron's Oscar frontrunner is a triumph|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/nov/27/roma-alfonso-cuaron-oscar-frontrunner-triumph|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 November 2018|issn=0261-3077|via=www.theguardian.com}}</ref> The project was produced by Cuarón, [[Gabriela Rodríguez]] and Nicolás Celis. The film debuted at [[75th Venice International Film Festival]], where it won the [[Golden Lion]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/alfonso-cuaron-new-movie-participant-media-1201855134/|title=Alfonso Cuaron Sets Mexican Family Drama as Next Film|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=8 September 2016|work=Variety|via=}}</ref> and was distributed to select theaters in Mexico and United States before its online release on [[Netflix]]. ''Roma'' was highly acclaimed upon release; among its accolades are two Golden Globes (Best Foreign Language Film and Best Director for Cuarón) and three Academy Awards (Best Director, Best Foreign Language Film, and Best Cinematography for Cuarón) out of a leading ten nominations.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2019-12-23|title=Netflix’s ‘Roma’ wins three Oscars, including Best Director (but not Best Picture)|url=http://social.techcrunch.com/2019/02/24/netflix-roma-oscars/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Andrew|last1=Pulver|accessdate=2019-12-23|title=Alfonso Cuarón wins Oscar for best director for Roma|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2019/feb/25/alfonso-cuaron-wins-best-director-oscar-for-roma|newspaper=The Guardian|date=25 February 2019|issn=0261-3077|via=www.theguardian.com}}</ref>

sections.title: American debut, ''Y Tu Mamá También'' and international success
sections.paragraphs:
[[File:Alfonso_Cuarón_y_Clive_Owen_(Children_of_men).jpg|left|thumb|250px|Alfonso Cuarón and [[Clive Owen]], who worked together on '' Children of Men''.]]

sections.title: Awards recognition
sections.paragraphs:
[[File:Alfonso_Cuarón,_President_jury_Venezia_72_(25805089406).jpg|thumb|250px|left|Cuaron at the [[72nd Venice International Film Festival]]]]

[[File:Alfonso Cuarón en Morelia.jpg|thumb|Alfonso Cuarón in Morelia International Film Festival]]

sections.title: Personal life
sections.paragraphs:
Cuarón is a vegetarian<ref name="vulture2013">{{ cite web | author = Dan P. Lee | work = [[New York (magazine)|New York]] | via = Vulture.com | url = http://www.vulture.com/2013/09/director-alfonso-cuaron-on-making-gravity.html | title = The Camera's Cusp: Alfonso Cuarón Takes Filmmaking to a New Extreme With Gravity |date=22 September 2013 |accessdate = 12 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{ cite web|url=https://www.loquetlondon.com/blog/sheherazade-goldsmith-vogue/ |title=Vogue Arts – Down to Earth |publisher=Loquet London |accessdate=26 July 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212115303/http://www.loquetlondon.com/blog/sheherazade-goldsmith-vogue/ |archivedate=12 December 2013 |date=12 December 2013}}</ref> and has been living in London since 2000.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/feb/16/baftas-2014-alfonso-cuaron-best-director-award Baftas 2014: Alfonso Cuarón wins best director for Gravity | Film]. theguardian.com. Retrieved on 2014-05-22.</ref>

Cuarón's first marriage was to Mariana Elizondo, with whom he has a son, [[Jonás Cuarón]], born in 1981, who is also a film director, known for ''[[Year of the Nail]]'' and ''[[Desierto]]''.<ref name="separation">{{cite news |title=Anuncia Cuarón separación matrimonial de su segunda esposa |url=http://www.cronica.com.mx/notas/2008/368822.html |accessdate=21 December 2018 |work=La Crónica |agency=NOTIMEX |date=23 June 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20181221014235/http://www.cronica.com.mx/notas/2008/368822.html |archivedate=21 December 2018 |language=Spanish }}</ref> His second marriage, from 2001 to 2008, was to Italian actress and freelance journalist Annalisa Bugliani, with whom he has two children.<ref name="separation"/>

He has publicly shown his fascination for the [[Esperanto language]] and his support for the [[Esperanto movement]].<ref>http://esperantodocumentary.com/blog/an-interview-with-director-alfonso-cuaron.html</ref> He called his production company ''[[Esperanto Filmoj]]''.
